Expose reactive configuration within your application with the App Config file.
config file to expose reactive configuration within your application with the ability to update it at runtime within lifecycle or using a nuxt plugin and editing it with HMR (hot-module-replacement).
You can easily provide runtime app configuration using
file. It can have either of
language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
Do not put any secret values inside
file. It is exposed to the user client bundle.
To expose config and environment variables to the rest of your app, you will need to define configuration in
, Nuxt uses Vite or webpack to bundle the code. We can universally access
both when server-rendering the page and in the browser using
language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

<script setup lang="ts">
const appConfig = useAppConfig()

console.log(appConfig.theme)
</script>
file at the root of the new
Nuxt tries to automatically generate a TypeScript interface from provided app config so you won't have to type it yourself.
However, there are some cases where you might want to type it yourself. There are two possible things you might want to type.
might be used by module authors who are declaring what valid
options are when setting app config. This will not affect the type of
language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
// It is always important to ensure you import/export something when augmenting a type
If you want to type the result of calling
, then you will want to extend
as you will overwrite the types Nuxt infers from your actually defined app config.
// This will entirely replace the existing inferred `theme` property
// You might want to type this value to add more specific types than Nuxt can infer,
Nuxt uses a custom merging strategy for the
This strategy is implemented using a
, which allows defining a custom merging strategy for every key in
that has an array as value.
The function merger can only be used in the extended layers and not the main
Here's an example of how you can use:
// Overwrite default array value by using a merger function

html .light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html.light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
The .nuxtignore file lets Nuxt ignore files in your project’s root directory during the build phase.
The app.vue file is the main component of your Nuxt application.
